comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: The Tampico Affair started off as a minor incident involving U.S. sailors and Mexican land forces loyal to General Victoriano Huerta during the guerra de las facciones phase of the Mexican Revolution. The misunderstanding occurred on April 9, 1914, but would fully transpire into the breakdown of diplomatic relations between the two countries, and the occupation of the port city of Veracruz for over six months. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_occupation_of_Veracruz en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampico_Affair

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Wystan -- Patched now (one "l"); we'll comb the database source records again and get a better handle on the mayor's name. -- Helena

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: May 11, 1914: the National Memorial Service for 17 U. S. sailors who died at Vera Cruz, Mexico, in April. The Memorial Service was held in New York City, with the President, the Secretary of the Navy, the Governor, and the Mayor in attendance. Story in the New York Times, 5/11/14: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=940CE3DB173AE6...

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Wystan, Thanks for your efforts with the numerous photographs which document the National Memorial Service of May 11, 1914. We will be able to better link the related images and expand the descriptions, including the addition of a date where one is not yet included. We will add Mr. Tumulty to this description as well. He is identified as Wilson's secretary in this photograph from one of our other collections, as you also point out in your note on this photo.
